The Quagmire Called the Iraq War (4 Letters)
 Published: July 4, 2005
 To the Editor:
 
 Re "Dangerous Incompetence," by Bob Herbert (column, June 30):
 
 As the dust settles from President Bush's speech on the war in Iraq, it is obvious that his hubris has left the American people in a precarious position. We are arguably living through the most harrowing time since the 1962 Cuban missile crisis.
 
 What is so frightening is that President Bush has painted us into a dangerously tight corner. The obvious solution is to cut and run: set a timetable, stanch the bleeding and withdraw. But that would be more dangerous than staying a course that the defense secretary has suggested might last a decade or more. 
 
 Why? Because the United States has no choice but to finish the job. Its failure to do so would be a victory for terrorists everywhere. 
 
 Shaun D. Mullen -- Newark, Del., June 30, 2005
 
 To the Editor:
 
 The Bush administration doesn't know how to prosecute this war or to end it successfully. But there's another reason we are stuck in Iraq. 
 
 The administration, in its way, finds the war congenial. As long as it goes on, the war drags America into lock step with President Bush. Iraq is a sort of daily 9/11 that keeps America fearful and keeps it marching, however disenchanted, to the president's beat.
 
 Whether purposely done or not, an age-old way to secure power and keep it is to keep a country fearful, aggressive, xenophobic and at war. This war of President Bush's continues to that.
 
 Stewart Dean -- Kingston, N.Y., June 30, 2005
 
 To the Editor:
 
 Thanks to Bob Herbert for reminding us how the situation in Iraq got so bad. "Bring 'em on" reflects how little comprehension President Bush has of how to bring democracy to the Middle East.
 
 I am still appalled and deeply embarrassed that the commander in chief can get away with such childish rhetoric. Even more embarrassing is that a number of Americans probably agreed with President Bush. 
 
 With the insurgency thriving, I hope that those who have supported Mr. Bush might recognize the awful situation his administration has led us into without any notion of how to get out.
 
 "Quagmire" is the correct term, and until a majority of Americans begins to wake up to that reality, extrication will be impossible. 
 
 We are effectively trapped in Iraq as surely as any hostage.
 
 Stefan Gutermuth -- Petaluma, Calif., June 30, 2005
 
 To the Editor:
 
 After reading Bob Herbert's columns of the last few weeks and watching Iraq unfold over the last two years, I have a question that I feel was never asked by our media and hence never answered by our government. 
 
 If it required 500,000 armed forces to remove Saddam Hussein from the little country of Kuwait in 1991, why did anyone think that it would be possible to keep the peace with one-third as many troops in a country many times larger? 
 
 Jonathan V. Porcelli -- Tucson, June 30, 2005
